security_audit.summary: This skill contains only Markdown documentation defining tool preset configurations. No executable code, scripts, network operations, or system access capabilities. Pure metadata/skill for agent configuration.

content.user_title: Define consistent tool presets for Claude Code agents
content.value_statement: Different tasks require different tool access. This skill provides standardized tool preset definitions so you can quickly configure agents with appropriate capabilities for development, research, file operations, analysis, or orchestration tasks.
actual_capabilities: Defines dev-tools preset (Read, Write, Edit, Bash) for coding agents
Defines file-ops preset (Read, Write, Edit, Grep, Glob) for file manipulation
Defines analysis preset (Read, Grep, Glob, Bash) for code review agents
Defines research preset (Read, Write, WebSearch, WebFetch) for information gathering
Defines orchestration preset (Read, Write, Edit, Task, TodoWrite) for multi-agent coordination
limitations: This is a configuration skill only, not a standalone agent
Requires Claude Code or compatible platform to use the presets
Does not execute tasks itself, only defines tool access for other agents

use_cases.title: Configure development agents
use_cases.description: Set up coding agents with Read, Write, Edit, and Bash tools for development tasks.

use_cases.title: Create file operation agents
use_cases.description: Build documentation agents with file search and edit capabilities without shell access.

use_cases.title: Orchestrate research workflows
use_cases.description: Deploy coordinator agents that manage sub-agents for complex research projects.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Development Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new agent using the dev-tools preset. It should have Read, Write, Edit, and Bash access for code development.

prompt_templates.title: Code Review Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up an agent with the analysis preset for code review. Include Read, Grep, Glob, and Bash for linter execution.

prompt_templates.title: Research Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an agent using the research preset. It needs WebSearch and WebFetch for web research plus Read and Write for documentation.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Agent Coordinator
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure an orchestration preset agent that can launch sub-agents using Task and track progress with TodoWrite.

output_examples.input: Create a development agent with the dev-tools preset
output: Agent configured with tools: Read, Write, Edit, Bash
Ready for coding, testing, and build tasks
Add this skill to your agent configuration to enable preset tool access

best_practices: Start with minimal tool presets and expand only when needed for specific tasks
Match preset selection to the actual requirements of your use case
Review agent tool access periodically to ensure least-privilege principles
anti_patterns: Using full-stack preset when only specific tools are needed
Mixing tools from different presets arbitrarily
Ignoring the principle of least privilege for agent tool access

faq.question: Which platforms support these tool presets?
faq.answer: These presets work with Claude Code and Codex. The skill defines tool configurations that these platforms recognize.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of tools an agent can use?
faq.answer: Platform limits vary. Start with minimal presets and expand only when required for specific task capabilities.

faq.question: Can I create custom tool presets?
faq.answer: Yes. Define custom presets following the pattern in SKILL.md with your specific tool combinations.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using these presets?
faq.answer: Presets only define tool access. Actual data safety depends on platform permissions and agent behavior.

faq.question: Why is my agent not recognizing the preset?
faq.answer: Ensure the skill is added to your agent configuration and the preset name matches exactly as defined.

faq.question: How do these presets differ from custom tool configurations?
faq.answer: Presets provide standardized, tested configurations for common use cases. Custom configurations offer flexibility for specific needs.
